Award.AwardTitle: Addressing Dynamic Donor:Acceptor and Electrode Interfaces in Organic Bulk-Heterojunction and Perovskite Solar Cells Under Device-Operating Condition

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Principal Investigator: Bin Hu
Number: 1438181

Nontechnical Description

The sun represents the most abundant potential source of pollution-free energy on earth. Solar cells for the conversion of sunlight to electricity, also known as photovoltaic (PV) solar cells, suffer from a variety of complicated electrical processes during their operation that lower the overall solar energy conversion efficiency. This project will develop and use a novel technique based on magnetic field measurements to probe these electrical processes at material interfaces within two major classes of photovoltaic devices, organic polymer based photovoltaic (OPV) solar cells, and perovskite material based semiconductor solar PV cells, while these devices are in actual operation. OPV devices offer promise because they can be made from relatively inexpensive organic polymer materials, and perovskite materials offer promise because they are obtained from minerals abundant in the earth?s crust and have relatively high solar energy conversion efficiencies. Fundamental understanding of the useful and non-useful photovoltaic processes at material interfaces within these PV materials will suggest materials synthesis pathways and device engineering that can potentially lead to increased solar energy conversion efficiency in both PV device classes. The proposed activities will also offer interdisciplinary opportunities to enhance class teaching, research training opportunities for students from under-represented groups in science and engineering, and outreach activities for high-school students on the topic of organic polymer based solar cells.

Technical Description

In a photovoltaic (PV) device, when a photon from sunlight is absorbed and converted into an electron-hole pair, there are several loss mechanisms which prevent the charge from being carried away from the device as electric current, resulting in lowered solar energy conversion efficiency. The overall goal of this project is to gain a fundamental understanding of these recombination loss mechanisms at material interfaces though a unique magnetic field measurement technique. Specifically, the project will make measurements of magnetic field induced photocurrent and photo-induced capacitance to probe the binding energy and charge transfer states of the dynamic donor/acceptor interface in excitonic organic polymer based photovoltaic (OPV) devices, and the electrode interface non-excitonic perovskite thin-film photovoltaic devices respectively, using real operating devices under device operating conditions. The proposed research will gain insights on how to tune the electron-hole binding energies at the donor/acceptor interface for excitonic, bulk hetero-junction OPV devices through control of polarization and energy parameters, and on how to enhance the charge collection at the electrode interface in non-excitonic perovskite thin-film PV devices through dielectric effects. The research plan will focus on three tasks, including materials processing and device engineering to tune polarization and energy parameters at donor/acceptor and electrode interfaces, experimental studies on the useful and non-useful photovoltaic processes occurring at donor/acceptor and electrode interfaces, and finally, elucidation on the key parameters that control the electron-hole binding energies at the donor/acceptor interface and the charge collection at electrode interfaces. Fundamental understanding of the useful and non-useful photovoltaic processes at dynamic donor/acceptor and electrode interfaces will suggest materials synthesis pathways and device engineering that can potentially lead to increased solar energy conversion efficiency in both excitonic, bulk-hetero-junction OPVs and non-excitonic perovskite thin-film PV devices. With respect to education and broadening participation, the proposed activities will also offer interdisciplinary opportunities to enhance class teaching, research training opportunities for students from under-represented groups in science and engineering, and outreach activities for high-school students on the topic of organic polymer based solar cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic solar cells are known as new renewable-energy devices, namely solution-processing thin-film devices that convert sunlight into electricity. Essentially, organic solar cells are designed by mixing donor and acceptor molecules to form an active layer where the light-electricity conversion is realized. Particularly, the light-electricity conversion relies on two critical interfaces: donor:acceptor interface and electrode interface. The donor:acceptor interface plays a crucial role in separating the incident light-generated excitons, named as high-binding-energy excitons due to the low dielectric constants in organic materials. The electrode interface is responsible for collecting the photogenerated carriers to generate an electric current. This project has made three major breakthroughs to further advance the research and development of organic solar cells.

 

 1.       Developing unique experimental methods

 

This project has, for the first time, developed two in-situ methods, magnetic field effects of photocurrent and light-assisted capacitance measurements, to monitor the donor:acceptor and electrode interfaces at device-operating condition during the development of photocurrent in organic solar cells [Advanced Materials, 26, 3956-3961]. The magnetic field effects of photocurrent provide a vital experimental tool to elucidate how the high-binding-energy excitons are separated at donor:acceptor interface. The light-assisted capacitance measurement can directly show the collection of separated excitons at electrode interface to form an electrical current. Therefore, these two in-situ methods provide powerful experimental tools to reveal the deeper parameters in controlling the light-electricity conversion through materials processing and device engineering.

 

2.       Revealing key parameters of controlling separation of high-binding-energy excitons

 

By using magnetic field effects of photocurrent, this project found that separating high-binding-energy excitons towards generating free charge carriers requires an electrical polarization induced by incident light, namely light-induced polarization. With this new concept, the project successfully demonstrated an important improvement on light-electricity conversion by incorporating intramolecular electron-withdrawing and electron-donating units to provide the necessary condition for establishing light-induced polarization [ACS Nano 2017, 11(11), 11542-11549]. Essentially, this leads to a significant enhancement on power-conversion-efficiency in organic solar cells. More importantly, by using this concept, the project has shown that the binding energies of excitons which are normally in the order of electron volts (eV) can be significantly reduced to milli-electron volts (meV) in organic materials by symmetrically introducing light-assistant polarization through symmetrically incorporating intramolecular electron-withdrawing and electron-donating units into macromolecular ring structures [Materials Horizons, DOI: 10.1039/C9MH01524H]. As a result, organic materials, namely high-binding-energy materials, are now very competitive with inorganic materials, namely low-binding-energy materials. This provides an opportunity to use organic materials in photodetector applications.

 

3.       Elucidating key parameters of controlling charge collection electrode interface

 

By using light-assisted capacitance measurement, the project found that surface polarization of transport layer plays an important role in collecting free charge carriers generated in an active photovoltaic layer. With this information, the project has demonstrated a large enhancement on photocurrent generation by using highly polarizable transport layer in organic solar cells [Advanced Materials, 30(11), 1705298; Advanced Energy Materials, 7(4), 1601575]. More importantly, this project has extended this concept to organic-inorganic hybrid perovskite solar cells that have recently become highly attractive thin-film solar cells with solution processing uniqueness. This leads to a large enhancement on light-electricity conversion in perovskite solar cells [Nano Energy, 36, 95-101,].
